facts.fact: The AGDS concept used twin 35mm auto-cannons and missile pods, aiming to wipe out air targets with brutal burst fire.
The ALVT was designed as a super-light tank hunter, prioritizing mobility over armor to strike and vanish.
The AMX-10 RC is amphibious—its hydro-pneumatic suspension lets it 'kneel' for better firing angles.
The BAT-4M is actually an engineering vehicle, using its power not to fight but to bulldoze, dig, and clear obstacles for armored units.
The FV4030 series helped lay the groundwork for advanced Chobham armor concepts used on later Western tanks.
The HSTV-L fired a hyper-velocity 75mm gun capable of flinging darts at extreme speeds for long-range penetration.
This Leopard variant featured the A1 series upgrades with improved fire control and stabilization for better first-shot accuracy.
The 1A6A1 was a late experimental Leopard fitted with thermal sights, giving it night-fighting capabilities far ahead of its era.
The Leopard 2FK concept swapped the main gun for anti-tank missile launchers—an unusual twist for a tank that normally relies on kinetic rounds.
This prototype era saw experimentation with modular armor packages that foreshadowed what modern 2A models eventually adopted.
Railgun Abrams concepts explored electromagnetic launch tech that could theoretically push penetrators past Mach 7.
The M1E1 was a testbed variant integrating early Abrams NBC protection systems and crew comfort upgrades for harsh environments.
The M3A1 cavalry version carried extra sensors and optics instead of infantry seats, turning the Bradley into a fast reconnaissance hunter.
The M60A3E2 tested enhanced armor blocks and fire control tweaks to squeeze more life out of the aging M60 platform.
The BOT variant simulates unmanned or automated evaluation setups used for gunnery training and robotics research.
The M60E2 mounted a different turret weapon system—famously including trials with aircraft-style machine gun setups.
Object 279’s UFO-like hull made it resistant to landmines and blast waves—one of the strangest tank shapes ever built.
Object 287 carried guided missiles in place of a traditional gun, representing the USSR’s brief fascination with gun-less tanks.
The PTZ-89C is a Chinese tank destroyer variant built around a 120mm gun designed specifically for long-range anti-armor shots.
The T-55 Enigma used improvised composite armor blocks that surprisingly resisted some early 90s anti-tank rounds.
The T-62AV added Kontakt-1 ERA, giving the old T-62 a substantial leap in survivability against shaped-charge weapons.
The T-62MS modernization added thermal sights and new electronics, pushing a 1960s tank into near-modern utility.
The T-64A pioneered composite armor and an autoloader—features that became Soviet design signatures.
The T-72AU field upgrade package mixed Kontakt-1 ERA, improved side armor, and updated optics for front-line survivability.
The T-72B featured a reinforced turret with advanced composite layers, giving it one of the toughest turret fronts of its time.
The XM1-90 concept explored a lighter Abrams fitted with a 90mm gun for experimental maneuver warfare roles.
The XM1-V variant was part of early Abrams prototyping, evaluating engine and transmission alternatives.
The XM551 Sheridan prototype led to one of the lightest U.S. air-droppable armored gun systems ever fielded.
The XM808 ‘Twister’ used an articulated dual-body chassis, giving it spider-like flexibility over rough terrain.
